text: * There are 13 physical block addresses in an i-node, each of these addresses is 3 bytes long. * The first ten block addresses refer directly to data blocks, the next refers to a first level index block (which holds the addresses of further data blocks), the next refers to a second level index block (which holds the addresses of further index blocks) and the last refers to a third level index block (which holds the addresses of further second level index blocks). * All physical addresses associated with a file are implicitly assumed to reside on the same disc, there is no facility whereby a file could span more than one disc.
